Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Evolution of the Hypocone in Microbats (Microchiroptera)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The addition of a hypocone, a fourth cusp, to the upper molar in mammals has been a common transition in dental evolution. Using suborder Microchiroptera (microbats) as a case study, the proposed research will examine the adaptive significance of the hypocone. This research will test whether the hypocone functions to increase tooth strength, by dissipating stress within the enamel to avoid tooth cracking. Finite Element Analysis, a computer simulation technique commonly used in engineering to assess how structures respond to physical loads, will be used to determine the strength attributes of teeth with and without hypocones. Ultimately, this work will examine how the hypocone?s role in tooth strength may have influenced the evolution of molar shape.

This project uses innovative computer modeling techniques to examine adaptation, a fundamental evolutionary concept. Facets of this work are applicable throughout the scientific community (from paleontologists studying the form and function of fossils to ecologists studying mammalian diversity patterns). Further, an understanding of adaptation is vital for anyone wanting to know how life has evolved. This work will encourage undergraduate participation in scientific research. All computer models will be submitted to the Morphobrowser and Digimorph online databases to allow access to both the scientific community and the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mammalian molar teeth provide a wonderful model for the study of the evolutionary concepts of adaptation (a trait brought about by natural selection that enhances fitness) and exaptation (a trait already present, but co-opted for a new use). This research focused on the fourth upper molar main cusp, the hypocone, and other expansions of the postero-internal region of the upper molar, known here as the talon, a region that varies tremendously among therian mammals. The goal of this project was to examine the potential functions of the talon to further understand its role as a tooth adaptation or exaptation. We used microbats (suborder Microchiroptera) as a case study for therian mammals, because the group varies greatly in molar shape (including presence, size, and shape of the talon), body size, and dietary preferences. Using microcomputed tomography scanning and three-dimensional rendering techniques, we found that the talon likely functions in several ways, providing new insights on its role in molar evolution.

            Across dietary groups, the presence of the talon results in an overall tooth shape that is lower in relief, meaning it is more rounded and flat. A tooth feature with low relief provides increased crushing function, such as the crushing performed by a mortar and pestle. Thus the increase in crushing function resulting from the presence of the talon suggests it is an adaptation for a frugivorous diet, since fruit pulp is best broken down by the crushing of fruit cells. The presence of a talon ideal for a crushing function in non-frugivorous bats, however, implies that non-diet specific factors have also contributed to talon evolution.

            To further explore potential non-diet specific functions of the talon, we examined what the size of the talon, relative to the rest of the tooth, could tell us about its evolution. We found that talon size scales with body size (larger animals tend to have larger talons). This finding may mean that the talon evolved to provide additional generalized food processing area to the tooth. And given that any increase in area of the tooth dedicated to food processing would result in increased food intake, the presence of the talon could allow for greater energy intake to meet the higher metabolic demands of a larger animal. In this way, the talon may represent an adaptation for the evolution of larger body size in therian mammals.

            We also found that tooth strength (resistance to enamel cracking) may have played a role in talon evolution. The presence of the talon increases the strength of the tooth in some situations, especially during the chewing of soft food where the greatest enamel strain is located near the base of the tooth. A reduction in the likelihood of tooth cracking provided by the talon would give a great fitness benefit to an animal whose livelihood relies on well-functioning teeth.

            The results of this project suggest that the talon may perform several functions, including crushing for the breakdown of fruit, increased generalized food breakdown in the presence of body size evolution, and increased tooth strength during the chewing of soft foods. The talon may be considered an adaptation providing an initial benefit (such as tooth strength), but also an exaptation for derived diets and body sizes. Although the evolution of the talon may be complicated, the cusp has played an impactful role in mammalian tooth evolution. Ultimately, this research offers insights into the fundamental questions driving evolutionary theory: What is this anatomical structure? What is its function? How did it come to be?
